part_of: Han Dynasty’s Expansion into Central Asia
location: Ferghana Valley, Central Asia (modern Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan)

causes: Emperor Wu of Han sought superior 'Heavenly Horses' from Ferghana to improve Chinese cavalry.
Dayuan refused to sell horses to Han envoys, killing the Chinese delegation.
Han China launched a military campaign to take the horses by force.
events_leading_up_to_war: Han envoys were humiliated and murdered in Ferghana.
Emperor Wu ordered a punitive military expedition led by General Li Guangli.

result.general: Han Dynasty victory after siege of Ferghana’s capital.
result.treaty: Ferghana agreed to send horses to China as tribute.
result.territorial_changes: Han gained control over trade routes in the region.

Han_Dynasty.dead: Over half of the original army due to battles and starvation

Dayuan_Ferghana.dead: Unknown but significant, city besieged and defeated

major_battles.name: Siege of Ershi
major_battles.description: Han forces surrounded and starved out Ferghana’s capital before storming the city.

texts.name: Records of the Grand Historian (Shiji)
texts.details: Detailed accounts of the war from Sima Qian.

archaeological_evidence.description: Found in Xinjiang, suggesting Greek influences in Ferghana.
Excavated remains of Ferghana warhorses in China.

political: Strengthened Han control over trade routes in Central Asia.
Ferghana became a tributary state to China.
long_term_effects: Heavenly Horses bred with Chinese stock, improving cavalry.
Expanded Chinese presence in the Silk Road trade network.

military: Showcased Han China's ability to project power far beyond its borders.
Demonstrated importance of siege warfare in ancient Central Asia.
political: Solidified Han influence over Central Asian city-states.
Marked the beginning of China’s long engagement with the Silk Road.
cultural: Ferghana’s Greek-influenced culture introduced new artistic styles to China.
Led to the glorification of cavalry in Han military tradition.
